abstract.p: Study by Fannie Fae shows half of all Americans expect that most home mortgages will be handled over Internet within five years, making it easier to compare lending options and to reduce discrimination in the borrowing process; only 2 percent of recent homebuyers completed entire mortgage approval process using the Web (S)

block.p: Half of all Americans expect that most home mortgages will be handled over the Internet within five years, making it easier to compare lending options and to reduce discrimination in the borrowing process, a new survey has found. The study, by Fannie Mae, a government-chartered corporation that buys home loans from banks and other lenders, found that nearly 30 percent of those polled would ''definitely or probably'' use the Internet to apply for a mortgage, up from 20 percent in 1996. Still, the Internet remains largely an information resource, as only 2 percent of recent homebuyers completed the entire mortgage approval process using the Web.
